title: 'Human Ken doll' blasts Channel 4 plastic surgery show as 'tasteless'
text:
Rodrigo Alves has criticised CHannel 4’s controversial new show The Surjury (Picture: Getty)

Rodrigo Alves, also known as the human Ken doll, has slammed Channel 4’s controversial new programme The Surjury.

Fronted by Caroline Flack, it will see people who want plastic surgery plead their case to a group of strangers who will then decide if they should go under the knife.

The 35-year-old, who became a household name through his desire to transform himself in a ‘Ken doll’, recently underwent his 70th surgery.

But he finds The Surjury ‘tasteless’ and fears it can lead to ‘regret’ and ‘complications’.

He told Metro.co.uk: ‘It sounds like a very bad idea because having body modifications and plastic surgery is a very personal thing and one must never be under influence of others’ judgment and opinion.

‘I find it tasteless and it puts pressure on people to maybe have a unwanted procedure and regret it, and come back for more which can lead to complications.’

Rodrigo recently spent four weeks in Tehran where he had an eye lift, chin-implants, face lift and his 11th rhinoplasty (nose job).

He’d previously revealed to Metro.co.uk that he’d been left feeling ‘anxious’ after having fibrosis removed from his face.

The star told us that he’d undergone a five hour operation to take out the ‘hard lumps.’

Rodrigo believes the bumps came from earlier procedures that involved soluble threads being injected in a spider web formation to tighten the face by stimulating the production of collagen.

‘I don’t recommend that treatment to anyone,’ he told us.

When asked about further surgery, the star added: ‘They will finally change my chin implant for a diamond shaped one, which will make my face look smaller, and my 11th nose job where he will use a cartilage from my rib.’

Rodrigo recently underwent his 70th surgery (Picture: Getty)

Plans for the series was announced at the beginning of the year, with Channel 4 stating: ‘From bum-lifts to nose jobs, sculpted abs to breast enlargements, The Surjury allows people to explore their choices more thoroughly.’

Ross McCarthy, executive producer for show creators Gobstopper Television, added: ‘This is a totally new way of doing peer-to- peer advice.

‘Our pitchers will either get the surgery they’ve always wanted, or a massive boost in confidence when the public rules they don’t need work at all!’

The premise of the show has been met with a mixed reaction, with presenter Caroline clashing with The Good Place star Jameela Jamil on social media, who compared The Surjury to Black Mirror.

Metro.co.uk has contacted Channel 4 for comment.
